localised_text.last_approved_text: A more traditional, unit-centric Total War battle experience.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Generals ride into battle accompanied by a unit of capable bodyguards.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Focuses on army-level tactics and manoeuvres, where calculated action rather than heroic abandon will win the day.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Focuses on army-level tactics and manoeuvres, where calculated action rather than heroic abandon will win the day.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Unit fatigue plays a more integral role in battle. As such, it is recommended to set the default battle move speed to walk (running may then be toggled via the on-screen button or by double-clicking when issuing move orders).

localised_text.last_approved_text: Generals ride into battle as single, powerful warriors who use larger-than-life abilities inspired by their feats in the Romance of the Three Kingdoms.

localised_text.last_approved_text: It is the folly of man that we presume to divine the motives of others too completely. \n\n The eunuchs, employed in myriad positions around the Han, were thought to be the best choice for bureaucratic roles as they cannot be motivated by dynastic desires. This belief allowed them to amass so much power that now they all but control the imperial court - rather than being obsessed with a legacy, the eunuchs are desirous of power for its own sake, and are partly responsible for leading the empire into this turmoil of civil war.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: It is the folly of man that we presume to divine the motives of others too completely. \n\n The eunuchs, employed in myriad positions around the Han, were thought to be the best choice for bureaucratic roles as they cannot be motivated by dynastic desires. This belief allowed them to amass so much power that now they all but control the imperial court - rather than being obsessed with a legacy, the eunuchs are desirous of power for its own sake, and are partly responsible for leading the empire into this turmoil of civil war.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is the folly of man that they presume to divine the motives of others too completely. 

 The Han eunuchs, employed in myriad positions throughout their empire, were given far too much power, using their bureaucratic roles to accrue great, unassailable power. But this is no longer the Han, and the eunuchs will no longer be allowed to amass power unchecked. 

 They now serve the government of the Bandit Queen and her followers, with baleful eyes and tempered blades watching at all times...

localised_text.last_approved_text: There is no denying that only [[i]]Tian[[/i]] can confer the Mandate of Heaven - the right to rule. \n\n And although the power of the emperors has waned in recent generations, with governance executed by chancellors and eunuchs, only the Celestial Son can preside over crucial religious and spiritual ceremonies. Men may lust for power all they wish, but only the emperor can maintain harmony between the realms of heaven, earth and man.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Imperial proclamations carry only as much weight as the material they are written on. 

 The Han government has issued countless edicts, demanding reports be filed. Although many are infrequently catalogued, one constant is the register of land of population - published with unfailing regularity, it has become vital to the business of everyday government; taxation and mandatory conscription hinges upon its data. 

 Local officials collect the data before sending it to the central authority, where it is put to use.

localised_text.last_approved_text: With insurrection rising in Han China, the Bureau of Banditry has become one of the state's highest offices. Established in the capital, the bureau is staffed by high-level clerks and secretariat, tasked with the most difficult and egregious of cases. \n\n Working together with the judiciary on pressing matters, the office monitors the arbitration of justice closely, ensuring that the central government ultimately controls the dispensation of punishment, not the commanderies.

localised_text.last_approved_text: With insurrection an almost-uncontrollable force in China, the creation of local patrols have become one of the most useful institutions. localised_text.last_approved_text:
The sprawling and far-reaching empire is constantly in need of civil servants. 

 A system was long ago established for men to enter into government work by recommendation. At first, wealth was the only measure - insulation against bribery and corruption - yet it was soon required that a candidate be recommended by his commandery. 

 Only those 'filial and incorruptible' individuals, with relevant experience, can be chosen. Yet over time the system has become inevitably infected by the hereditary trappings of nepotism.

 Only those 'filial and incorruptible' individuals, with relevant experience, can be chosen. Yet over time the system has become inevitably infected by the hereditary trappings of nepotism.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
China is sprawling, and its governance in constant need of civil servants. 

 The Han established their system of allowing men to enter into government work by recommendation. Initially, wealth was the only measure, but soon the candidates had to be vouched for by the commandery. 

 They sought out the 'filial and incorruptible', but now we shall press those into service that are required, and those opposed will remain silent, or face the Bandit Queen's ire.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The baser instinct of man is to acquire power and then, by any means, defend it. 

 The eunuchs, allowed to accrue an irresponsible level of influence, have appointed themselves to administrative positions - influential roles such as 'regional inspector'. Thus, under the guise of streamlining communication, the eunuchs report only to themselves, keeping a constant control of the information flow in the empire. 

 To subvert the will of the emperor is to erode the Mandate of Heaven itself!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The baser instinct of man is to acquire power and then, by any means, defend it. 

 The eunuchs were allowed to accrue an irresponsible level of influence under the Han, appointing more and more of themselves to myriad administrative positions. They reported only to themselves, holding all the keys and guarding all the doors. No longer. 

 The Bandit Queen watches her administrators closely - the eunuchs will now work as clerks under superiors who will watch their every move. Any untoward activity will see them put swiftly to death.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The right man can wield supreme power by simple virtue of his position and his desire. localised_text.last_approved_text:
For those who commit the worst of all crimes, only the most severe penance awaits. 

 The 'Application of the Five Punishments' began as grievous mutilation of the condemned before death, involving tattooing of the face, removal of the nose, and amputation of the feet. 

 These truly egregious tortures were abolished as the Han grew, replaced with bastinado - foot whipping. However, the sentence is still known, due to its history, as the 'five punishments'; a grim reminder to convicts how lucky they are by comparison.

localised_text.last_approved_text: As an empire grows, so too do its dependencies and agencies. Bureaucracy grows and distends, like a bloated sow, manifesting in multitudes of agencies and commissioners controlling every aspect of the economy. \n\n The commissioners of passage are chiefly concerned with the movement of people and goods across the empire, to facilitate large-scale, government-led endeavours. Establishing farms and colonies on the fringes of Han territory is one, to ensure the border lands became prosperous additions to the empire.

Bureaucracy grows and distends, like a bloated sow, manifesting in multitudes of agencies and commissioners controlling every aspect of the economy. \n\n The commissioners of passage are chiefly concerned with the movement of people and goods across the land, to facilitate large-scale, government-led endeavours. Establishing farms and colonies on fringe territories is one, to ensure the border lands became prosperous additions to the bandits' growing realm.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
All things under heaven must be watched, lest man become overzealous. 

 The Han keep a steady hand on nearly every aspect of the empire's production. Notably, the state has established a staggering thirty-four agencies for regulating the iron and salt industries. They all report back to the central government, whose control of these industries allows the state to maintain viability against private merchants. 

 The greed of the opportunistic must be kept in check, lest it overwhelm all else.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Although divinely ordained, the empire cannot survive on heavenly will alone. 

 Taxation sustains government, and tax is a surety in Han China. All citizens must pay a poll tax - paid in cash - based on their profession and means. Farmers also pay a land tax, in the form of a fraction of their harvest. Land and slave-owning citizens are taxed at a much higher rate, whilst merchants pay less. 

 Paying in kind is often a common replacement for cash - silk or floss is often more valuable than any coin...

localised_text.last_approved_text: For every rule, there must be exceptions, just as for every problem there is no single solution. China is broadly divided into commanderies, with each governing itself relatively independently. \n\n However, the urban centres of the empire have much denser populations, and so cities are split into discrete districts, individually administered by a superintendent. These men are powerful indeed, yet still exist below the nine ministers of state; the power of the city is great, but not greater than the power of the empire.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is said that the emperor shall reign with folded arms, his thoughts concealed and his nature implacable. 

 Heaven's chosen is a practitioner of [[i]]Wu-Wei[[/ii]] - to behave without contrivance, 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The 'irksome' daily duties are delegated to subordinates, who are expected to anticipate the emperor's will and enact legislation accordingly. 

 Failure, however, reflects on both the emperor and his staff, so it falls upon them to warn their liege if the path he walks seems unwise.

It is said that the emperor shall reign with folded arms, his thoughts concealed and his nature implacable. 

 Heaven's chosen is a practitioner of [[i]]Wu-Wei[[/ii]] - to behave without contrivance, 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The 'irksome' daily duties are delegated to subordinates, who are expected to anticipate the emperor's will and enact legislation accordingly. 

 Failure, however, reflects on both the emperor and his staff, so it falls upon them to warn their liege if the path he walks seems unwise.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is said that the emperors of the old order were to reign with folded arms, their thoughts concealed and their natures implacable. 

 This is to behave without contrivance - known as [[i]]'Wu-Wei'[[/i]] - 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The emperor's whims were to be anticipated and executed. 

 Now, however, the Bandit Queen and her followers prosecute a more direct style of governance; respect - and fear - shall instil a reverence of the leader, not some celestial gift, and their actions shall be carried out because the alternative is far, far worse...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
How best to ensure the legacy of an empire? 

 Coins establish power; they last forever and clearly signify from whence they came. The Han, much like previous dynasties, are most concerned with establishing a single, central currency to cement power over the economy. 

 Yet as time passed and different kings have vied for control, minted currency has reflected this disunity; in the failing light of the Han, warlords attempt to mint their own legitimacy.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Heavenly Son, chosen by the [[i]]Tian[[/i]] to rule all under heaven, is granted power and authority by the Mandate of Heaven. The mandate is the natural plan and order of the universe, bestowed upon a just ruler. \n\n Lineage and nobility is irrelevant before the will of heaven, and the mandate can be lost as easily as it is given. Earthquakes, famines and other natural disasters are portents of heaven's displeasure in its chosen, and it is believed the mandate has passed when revolution successfully overthrows the emperor.

The empire spans beyond mortal gaze, past borders and belief. 

 Our land is gifted by the divine, yet there are incendiary elements who will resist all the same. To combat them, the Han assigned each region a commissioner, granted the autonomy to raise armies and prosecute justice in the emperor's name. 

 Yet decentralising the state's power allowed lesser men to amass their own strength, enough to even challenge the legitimacy of the emperor's mandate itself...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
If a man is able to lift a sword and fight, then his empire expects it of him. 

During their two-year mandatory military service, conscripts spend one year training, then another on garrison duty. Before the chaos, this meant a secondment to the imperial capital, stationed as guards or at the whim of the palace commandant. 

 In some cases, however, the Han deploy these fresh troops to the frontline, where they prosecute the military campaigns of the emperor.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
If a man is able to lift a sword and fight, then his empire expects it of him. 

During their two-year mandatory military service, conscripts spend one year training, then another on garrison duty. Before the chaos, this meant a secondment to the imperial capital, stationed as guards or at the whim of the palace commandant. 

 In some cases, however, the Han deploy these fresh troops to the frontline, where they prosecute the military campaigns of the emperor.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The Bandit Queen and her followers need men to fight their wars and defend their lands, and the men required to fight those wars will be drafted, one way or another. 

 Previously, under the Han, able-bodied men were drafted into two-year, mandatory military service, where they spent one year training and another on garrison duty - usually seconded to the imperial capital. 

 The Bandits see no reason to change this working method, adapting it only enough to suit their needs - whilst under the Han this fighting spirit was expected, now it is [[i]]demanded[[/i]].

localised_text.last_approved_text: Penance is paid in whatever way the state sees fit. Criminals, damned to a life under the thumb of imperial justice, are often drafted into the military when the need is great; when regular conscripts and volunteers are not enough. \n\n Particularly under the Han, this became a burden of necessity rather than obligation. Most often, these convict drafts end up posted to the north-western outposts, manning the defences against whatever threats lie beyond the borders...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Those who are able to serve, should serve - this is the law of the empire. 

 At the age of twenty-one, the Han conscript all able-bodied men for two years; one for training, and another serving as garrison troops. Even when relinquished from their obligation, these men often join militias in their home regions, reforming during emergencies into a fighting force. 

 It is only at the age of fifty-six that the Han finally relieve these men of any military obligation - peace is a privilege earned only through vigilance.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Those who are able to serve, should serve - this is the law of the empire. 

 At the age of twenty-one, the Han conscript all able-bodied men for two years; one for training, and another serving as garrison troops. Even when relinquished from their obligation, these men often join militias in their home regions, reforming during emergencies into a fighting force. 

 It is only at the age of fifty-six that the Han finally relieve these men of any military obligation - peace is a privilege earned only through vigilance.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Any who are able to serve, should serve - this is the unwritten law of the land. 

 Those who first came to serve the Bandit Queen did so out of loyalty - or perhaps fear yet they served all the same. Whilst the Han conscripted men into military service as a societal obligation, Zheng Jiang and her bandits fought out of necessity. 

 The Han let their soldiers retire after two years, yet the new regime cannot cease. Their armies must stand tall, and numerous, and ready, to answer the constant call to war!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
As the power of the Han wanes, those who are able to muster their own forces do so. 

 Whilst noblemen are able to swiftly amass a following, there is also a mustering of forces more locally; in regions where the Han's influence is weakest, provincial military forces coalesce around local figures, who then use these forces to defend their lands. 

 They also bring these retainer armies with them when pledging loyalty to another, more powerful leader - those who now stake their claim to China's throne.

As the power of the Han wanes, those who are able to muster their own forces do so. 

 Whilst noblemen are able to swiftly amass a following, there is also a mustering of forces more locally; in regions where the Han's influence is weakest, provincial military forces coalesce around local figures, who then use these forces to defend their lands.

localised_text.last_approved_text: In the vacuum left by the Han, Zheng Jiang rose, and now she and her followers are charged with holding onto the power they have seized. Those who have fought alongside her - those whose loyalty is unwavering and unquestioned - have earned the right to muster troops and lead them into battle. \n\n As the bandits grow in power and territory, there is great need of these ringleaders - men and women who can gather together others willing - or at least ready - to fight, and pressing them towards the front line.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A horse can be a steadfast companion, but without proper equipment, an unreliable friend in battle. Why risk defeat, when the chariot is stronger and more effective? \n\n That was the case until the development of the stirrup, which has allowed horseback warfare to become more dependable and, vitally, powerful. This, combined with the burgeoning trade in horses, makes shock cavalry a viable and, when used correctly, explosive tool in a warlord's arsenal.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When there is an urgent need, the empire will call upon you. And if you can, you will answer. 

 So it is with all able-bodied men; even though their compulsory military service is only two years, upon returning home they are expected to serve in militias, ready to reform and serve when the state calls them to battle. 

 During emergencies, those currently serving can have their conscriptions extended, and some may even be recalled - all of the empire must rise to face a looming threat!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
When there is an urgent need, the empire will call upon you. And if you can, you will answer. 

 So it is with all able-bodied men; even though their compulsory military service is only two years, upon returning home they are expected to serve in militias, ready to reform and serve when the state calls them to battle. 

 During emergencies, those currently serving can have their conscriptions extended, and some may even be recalled - all of the empire must rise to face a looming threat!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
If the regime needs you, you will be called. And you will answer. 

 The Han leaned on their system of compulsory military service, but Zheng Jiang and her bandits believe something more permanent is required. All must be ready to fight, if they are able, and conscription will continue during times of great need until the bandit leaders are satisfied. 

 For when new threats loom - and so many do - they must be faced with as much strength as can be mustered!

localised_text.last_approved_text: China is a land of extremes - mighty peaks gaze down from the heavens, whilst deep ravines peer up from below. Between the troughs and gouges of the earth, mighty rivers criss-cross the country, making perfect natural highways for transportation. \n\n The mighty, vast vessels that convey both military and economic power across China are known as 'Green Dragon' ships. Whosoever controls the rivers, then, could be said to control China itself.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
There are many ways to curry favour with the emperor, and many ways in which he may repay that service. 

 One such repayment emperors prefer is one of feoffment - the granting of land and titles to relatives, descendants and loyal friends of the ruling family. 

 These gifts are given with the proviso that, in wartime, the emperor can call on them, and know that they will answer.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
There are many ways to curry favour with the emperor, and many ways in which he may repay that service. 

 One such repayment emperors prefer is one of feoffment - the granting of land and titles to relatives, descendants and loyal friends of the ruling family. 

 These gifts are given with the proviso that, in wartime, the emperor can call on them, and know that they will answer.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
There are many who wish to curry favour with the ruler, and many ways in which such favour may be repaid. 

 Those who climb to the very top of the ladder, the rewards bestowed by a grateful ruler could be fine indeed. 

 Under the Han, loyal and noble subjects were granted titles and lands, and this remains a perfectly fine method of repayment. Bandit leaders, as thanks for their service, were given their own lands and commanderies to oversee, establishing their own network of 'nobles' beneath the new regime.

localised_text.last_approved_text: One of the earliest, and most enduring rules of battle is that position is key. In strategic terms, this is the placement of defences and fortresses. Not only must be a fort be strong and well-manned, but so placed as to make it as difficult for an attacker to overcome. \n\n Upon hills and along the banks of rivers, the earth provides natural barriers to besieging forces, who face the prospect of dramatic losses if they wish to successfully seize the defences.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A man may hold vast lands, but no longer is that the total measure of his wealth. localised_text.last_approved_text: The economy of China is wracked by instability, stemming from the ongoing wars and feuds between warlords. As the new regime assume power, it behoves them to engage in the less dramatic business of stabilising their economy. \n\n A long period of unstable - or entirely absent - official government has left the economy, and myriad currencies, in shambles. By abolishing these illegitimate currencies and taking direct control of industries, Zheng Jiang and her followers intend to control and ease the flailing economy of the realm.

localised_text.last_approved_text: All things must start from humble beginnings - even the towering walls along the border start with simple, strong foundations. Even during hardships, if one can not take even small pleasures then theirs is a life out of balance. 

 The Office of Arts & Crafts endures, for even when the people are displeased at state control of industry, the craftsmen and artisans of China are rightly revered. Items of wood, lacquer and jade remain highly desirable, and the artisans themselves enjoy a healthy state income.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Men will always come together in pursuit of a common purpose: wealth.

When the shih-chang organises merchants according to their wares, it is only natural that they will band together into associations - 'hang' - to co-operate in the name of mutual profit. 

When a more basic compassion does not motivate them, merchants' lust for riches will drive them to unity.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Men will always come together in pursuit of a common purpose: wealth.

When the shih-chang organises merchants according to their wares, it is only natural that they will band together into associations - 'hang' - to co-operate in the name of mutual profit. 

When a more basic compassion does not motivate them, merchants' lust for riches will drive them to unity.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Han allowed merchants and entrepreneurs to run all-but free, extorting both the government and the people. This was the Han's weakness, and one that Zheng Jiang and her new administration are keen to avoid. \n\n All the same, the bandit rulers nevertheless recognise the need for merchants, but endeavour to keep a tighter control on the hang - trade associations - so that merchants may still profit, but not free of tax - ultimately, it is the state who must benefit the most.

Without filtration, the miners succumb to the fumes and meet a tragic end.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Greed and opportunity are a potent tonic, and man will always resort to his baser instincts, given the opportunity. The Han administrators have seen fit to release their grip on the economy, allowing enterprising private magnates - the Hao Yu - to exploit the markets for profit. \n\n It is a cruel justice, then, that the Han have been forced to buy vast stocks of horses for their war efforts at exorbitant costs. The folly of the ruling class is balanced by the savvy of the common man.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Greed and opportunity are a potent tonic, and man will always resort to his baser instincts, given the opportunity. The Han administrators have seen fit to release their grip on the economy, allowing enterprising private magnates - the Hao Yu - to exploit the markets for profit. \n\n It is a cruel justice, then, that the Han have been forced to buy vast stocks of horses for their war efforts at exorbitant costs. The folly of the ruling class is balanced by the savvy of the common man.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The Han, in their arrogance, were exploited by magnates; forced to buy back their own resources - like horses for cavalry - from those canny merchants who saw the opportunity for profit. 

 Whilst the bandits cannot - unfortunately - do away with all these thieving entrepreneurs, their power and influence can be curtailed. They will become a rarer breed of citizen, forced to live by new rules that benefit the government, or face extinction. 

 The folly of the Han will not be repeated again.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The earth provides plenty for the resourceful. 

 The process of Hangtu - 'rammed earth' - was used long before the Han, and still endures. A damp mixture of earthen materials - chalk, lime, gravel, earth - is packed between a temporary frame. It is so densely packed that, when the frame is removed, the mixture hardens and stands independently, with surprising durability. 

 All across the land, structures rise and endure on foundations of Hangtu - even sections of the Great Wall itself are built from such methods.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If it can be dreamed, then in China it can be made. Since the time of Wu, smiths were creating blast furnaces of staggering temperatures; so much so that by the time of Han such endeavours were a state monopoly. \n\n Stalwart metallurgists could even blend different types of alloys together, creating something stronger than both. Texts speak of the blade of Liu Bang - the first Han Emperor - "harmonising the hard and the soft" when made; perhaps he too wielded a blade of such finesse...

localised_text.last_approved_text: Balance in all things, or else chaos. The power of the government must be balanced by the private citizen, and likewise the aspirations of the citizen must be checked by government control. \n\n The private entrepreneur would levy the peasants to aid in their endeavours, drawing them away from the agricultural toil so vital to China. By leveraging the slave population, the state can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the state.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Balance in all things, or else chaos. The power of the government has, in the past, been balanced by the private citizen, but now the aspirations of the citizen must be more closely checked by government control. 

 The private entrepreneur would levy the peasants to aid in their endeavours, drawing them away from the agricultural toil so vital to China. 

 By leveraging the slave population, the new government can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the ever-watchful administrators.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Whatever laws the state enforces to restrict the merchant class, enterprising men will find ways around them. Han law prohibits the merchant class from, amongst other things, having any sway in government affairs, yet their power and influence is nevertheless felt. \n\n Mercantile envoys often strike out beyond the borders along the Silk Road with Chinese goods, returning with exotic items that delight the aristocracy and make friends of those in power - there are always ways and means of making yourself heard.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Not everyone can be chosen for an academic life, but those who are have a duty to learn. 

 Private tutoring is handled by those with expertise in the matters and bureaucratic processes of state. At first, this education was small in scale - almost intimate - but over time the classes have bloated from groups of approximately ten to number in the thousands. 

 Increased bureaucracy has a cost measured in weeks, months and years...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Not everyone can be chosen for an academic life, but those who show intellect are brought to understand - and show loyalty to - the bandit cause. 

 Private tutoring is handled by those with expertise in matters of bureaucracy, teaching students the manners of government in much the same way that the Han once did. 

 These educations have bloated since the early Han days, with classes now numbering into the thousands - all to furnish the growing bandit administration with wisdom...

For if the state is to succeed, so too must its people.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
As the new regime expands, it seeks toil and excellence from every man, from every province, to help lead the administration. 

 Those who joined Zheng Jiang's crew of bandits were chiefly concerned with violence - particularly towards the Han, but those who showed particular aptitude and skill were marked by ringleaders for a greater purpose. 

 Whenever these talented elements were identified, they would be selected, then trained to become the next caste of leaders in the regime.

localised_text.last_approved_text: There is more beyond the misted borders of our lands than venom and enigma; there is opportunity and knowledge. The efforts of Zhang Qian, our most esteemed diplomat, led us to first contact with the [[i]]Daqin[[/i]] - foreign powers beyond our control. \n\n Through his work, the great and prosperous Silk Road was established, bringing wealth and culture to our lands. There has even been fleeting contact with the vast and proud empire hailing from the farthest west, seeking greater relations with the Han.

localised_text.last_approved_text: To master the art of disguise is to be sight unseen - known but never considered. The best spies are those who, through their actions, fulfil their duties in such a way that the reality of the deed may never truly be known. \n\n Sun Tzu dictates that a spy who cannot effectively do this cannot be suffered, and must be put to death. The master of disguise is a subtle influencer that sways the course of history without attracting attention; a wind that does not move a single blade of grass, yet shifts the very mountains.

localised_text.last_approved_text: What generosity you are paid, you must repay ten-fold. Men and women who come to be in in the service of another have many reasons; they may flee from the authorities or other pursuers. In exchange for their safety, sustenance and protection, their new masters demand absolute loyalty. \n\n In service to their lord, these retainers gather information on enemies and rivals - and even attempt assassinations, should it be requested of them. Men may be fickle, but loyalty is eternal.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is an established truth that some are born to govern, whilst others are not. 

 The [[i]]shih[[/i]] - 'educated gentlemen' - are the ideal that all imperial citizens should aspire to. Social status is vital, and so the Han state circulates criteria by which a [[i]]shih[[/i]] may be judged. 

 Although largely anecdotal, the examples of citizens demonstrating [[i]]shih[[/i]] behaviour both prove aspirational to others, and also show that the shih are of greater benefit to the empire than others.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Although it may rarely be codified, there is a code of honour that exists between bandits - a spoken but unwritten understanding that their lives are linked, and bound by a fellowship of acceptable behaviour. \n\n Particularly amongst the ringleaders and rulers of the Bandit administration, it is understood that, whilst they are not the [[i]]shih[[/i]] gentlemen of the Han, they are duty-bound to show respect and deference to one another, even if they show nothing but barbarity to their enemies.

localised_text.last_approved_text: What is good for the aristocrat is not always good for the common citizen. Whilst the nobility fritter away hours on [[i]]Go[[/i]], the rest of China enjoy a simpler, more elegant game; [[i]]Liu Bo[[/i]] - 'six sticks'. \n\n The origin of [[i]]Liu Bo[[/i]] is shrouded in mystery and obscured by legend, but what is certain is that it has been played since long before the Han. [[i]]Liu Bo[[/i]] forges links between people, and brings balance during uncertain times.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When the questions of economic management arise, there are many who wish to provide answers. 

 In the early days of the Han, it was they who exercised most of the economic power through state-controlled industry. As the dynasty grew and began to fracture, however, the economy began to decentralise into the hands of private magnates. 

 The obvious result? A vastly unequal distribution of wealth. The peasants now become poorer and the nobles become richer. This imbalance in society reflects the imbalance of the heavens...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When the questions of economic management arise, there are many who wish to provide answers, but only one wo can. 

 Under the Han, it was the state itself that exercised most of the economic power through state-controlled industry. Now, however, Zheng Jiang and her followers envision another method - one that requires much more direct oversight. 

 The markets must be administered correctly, and to that end bandit leaders are dispatched to all corners of the realm, to directly ensure - under a watchful eye - that things run smoothly.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Far beyond the Western Regions are peoples of different ways; those who dwell in the [[i]]Daqin[[/i]] know our land as [[i]]Serica[[/i]] -'land of silk'. localised_text.last_approved_text: The divine manipulation of threads, according to master Sun, is a "sovereign's most precious faculty". He who controlled the five spies - the local spy, the inward spy, the converted spy, the doomed spy and the surviving spy - has total mastery of his information networks. \n\n Ensuring these spies are all treated equally is crucial to their success, argues master Sun, as is making sure any spy who acts out of line is put to death. Subterfuge must be merciless; information does not discriminate.

localised_text.last_approved_text: China is supported by strong agricultural foundations, but upon that solid bedrock there is a towering wealth of luxury goods. The wider world cares not for Chinese farms, but our silks and spices are viewed most avariciously from afar. \n\n Although some argue that these frivolous items bring no direct benefit to China, trading them with distant nations funds both the imperial war chest, and the lives of luxury for those involved with the exchanges.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
What cannot be regulated by the empire is doomed to fall into the hands of those much less concerned with the welfare of its citizens. 

 Whilst the urban administrators of the Han are often accused of facilitating needlessly lavish lifestyles, the private merchants who have seized control of key industries as the government decentralises are equally to blame. 

 By gouging prices on grain and other crucial supplies, they drive their own personal profit at the expense of the entire empire.

localised_text.last_approved_text: For every purpose there is a tool, and for every role there is a man. As fire burns that to which it is applied, and as water quenches unruly flames, so too does every task have a fitting and appropriate executor. \n\n So it was that great men set out to document and enshrine the best manner in which the correct players may be found for every game. These treatises on human nature delve deep into the manner of one's mind and actions, and how best they may be understood and harnessed for the betterment of all.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Greater tranquillity can only be achieved through purification; this is what it is to achieve the Way of Great Peace. 

 The ideals of foreign neighbours - Indian Buddhism, nirvana - have all fed into our understanding of the universe. Taoism is born of that understanding; it maintains that the Mandate of Heaven has been lost due to the 'corruption' and 'pollution' of man; only through purification can it be reclaimed and restored. 

 It follows that any emperor afflicted by this corruption must be 'purified' too...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The Han understanding of the universe is derived from The Book of Great Peace - a tome that expands the ideas of Taoism; balance, harmony, purification. 

 Zheng Jiang's understanding of the universe is derived from the bond formed between her and her bandit cohorts, and the code of honour they have established with one another. 

 As the bandit regime becomes established, the time has come to consider the ideology that drives both their domestic and foreign policy; perhaps some hybrid of their practical, fraternal ideals and more celestial ideologies is the key...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When the farmer can work more efficiently, and achieve greater results, then it is all who benefit. 

 The development and proliferation of iron tools across China, partly sponsored by the Han state, helped to strengthen the country's agricultural backbone. Iron ploughshares work fields deeper and, combined with improvements to irrigation systems, mean that crops produce greater yields, and faster. 

 Truly, China thrives or falls on the bounty of its harvests.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Like moths to light, peasants will drift in the direction of wherever there is opportunity, for the sake of prosperity or - as is more likely - survival. 

 The Han have attempted to combat what they call the 'peasant problem' by incentivising the peasants not to migrate, offering them tax relief and high-quality tools, even during times of relatively bounteous harvests. 

 When the state comes bearing gifts, there may be wisdom in not questioning their motives.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Han live by a mantra; when the peasant thrives, so too does China. The farmers who toil the fields are required to give either tax or a share of their harvest as tithes to the landowner. \n\n Despite this, the state ensures that agriculture is taxed as little as possible. This is a noble principle, yet avaricious magnates will always be able to twist government generosity to benefit their own determined greed.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Han live by a mantra; when the peasant thrives, so too does China. The farmers who toil the fields are required to give either tax or a share of their harvest as tithes to the landowner. \n\n Despite this, the state ensures that agriculture is taxed as little as possible. This is a noble principle, yet avaricious magnates will always be able to twist government generosity to benefit their own determined greed.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When the peasant thrives, he is compliant. And when the peasant thrives, and pays his tithes and shares upwards, the landowner thrives too. 

 The regime watches this dynamic carefully, baleful as they are of the rich magnates who have helped drive the Han state they so despised. 

 Yet wealth has its advantages, as does keeping the rich on-side. They may be detestable, but they may also be useful.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
With metal, earth can be broken and tamed. High-quality tools, forged of iron, are distributed by the Han to peasants who have agreed not to resettle - a reward, of sorts, for their compliance.

 Iron ploughshares, along with gifted oxen, are able to furrow the land much deeper than other tools, with some degree of depth control, allowing for much more efficient and reliable crop cycles. 

 As iron endures, so too will the crops sown in its wake.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Water flows - it will always flow. It is persistent and, ultimately, unstoppable, yet when man takes to the waves it must be controlled. To this end, the interior of junk ships are segmented by bulkheads that span the length of the vessel. \n\n These transverse bulkheads are watertight - so any intruding water is contained, assuming the damage is not too severe, allowing the precious cargo within to (mostly) survive. Man cannot hold back the tide forever, but maybe just for a time is enough...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The cornerstone of agriculture, much like warfare, is separating what is useful from what is not. 

 The art of winnowing - dividing needless chaff from the grain - was originally a rudimentary process, involving throwing threshed crops into the air, and letting the wind separate the husks. 

 Ever-inventive farmers, however, soon created devices to improve this method; the 'winnowing fan' creates its own airstream, making the separation process faster and more reliable.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When disaster strikes, it is incumbent upon the ruler to soothe the pains of the people. 

 Since its earliest days, the Han Dynasty have provided aid to those affected by disasters like locusts, floods, earthquakes or epidemics. The state showed its compassion most often by lessening or removing land and straw taxes and opening granaries to provide direct relief. 

 Disaster is a sign from heaven of displeasure with the emperor; by aiding the stricken people, perhaps that celestial favour can be regained...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
When disaster strikes, it is incumbent upon the ruler to soothe the pains of the people. 

 Since its earliest days, the Han Dynasty have provided aid to those affected by disasters like locusts, floods, earthquakes or epidemics. The state showed its compassion most often by lessening or removing land and straw taxes and opening granaries to provide direct relief. 

 Disaster is a sign from heaven of displeasure with the emperor; by aiding the stricken people, perhaps that celestial favour can be regained...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When disaster strikes, the compassion of the ruler may soothe the pains of the people. 

 The old Han dynasty used to provide aid to those affected by disasters like locusts, floods, earthquakes or epidemics. Now, Zheng Jiang and her government show that they, too, have compassion by continuing to remove the tax on land and straw, and opening granaries to provide direct relief to the suffering. 

 Disaster is said to be a sign of displeasure from heaven; even Zheng Jiang must understand that letting the people suffer risks further condemnation from above...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When man is left with freedom unchecked, his vices will surely consume him. Chinese magnates, drunk on the idea of industrial monopoly, have to be kept in line. 

 The Han have taken control of industries, in particular the grain industry, establishing what has become known as 'ever-level granaries'. These storehouses regulate the price of grain by buying it when it is cheap and selling it at a low price when merchants try gouging for profit. 

 The state thus manages to stabilise the market, whilst also turning a profit.

localised_text.last_approved_text: All things need sustenance to survive; crops, as well as men, must be fed if they are to thrive. For the harvest to succeed it requires, above all else, water - in vast quantities. To meet these requirements, either canals must be dug or rivers dammed to form reservoirs. \n\n Canals are mostly state-funded due to their vast financial and logistical demands, whilst reservoirs are often funded by wealthy families. Although the state often aids these processes, the rich ensure their influence over China never wanes...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When the wind howls and the ocean writhes, the junk boat weathers the tumult with stalwart determination. 

 Built to withstand, junks have thick sails and wide holds, so that they can carry troops and supplies long distances, relatively safe from the perils of the elements. 

 When the junk strikes out onto the waves, thoroughly laden with cargo, the warlord can rest easy.

localised_text.last_approved_text: We derive sustenance from the earth, and so understanding its intricacies is vital. So thought Fan Shengzhi, who codified his thinking into 'The Book of Fan Shengzhi', a detailed document of agricultural practices that has become a manual of sorts for those toiling the field. \n\n It contains information on both basic farming theory, whilst also detailing more specific crops, from wheat to mulberries. Fan Shengzhi relates all of this relative to yin and yang, imploring us to seek balance and harmony, working with the earth for our benefit.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
From the peasant, the earth is toiled. From the landowner, the peasant is toiled. 

 'Sharecropping' is the process by which a landowner allows farmers to work his land, providing them tools, livestock and even lodgings. In exchange, the farmer supplies half - or sometimes two thirds - of the land's harvest. 

 Whilst used extensively by private landowners, the state also uses this method when settling peasants on state-owned land. For even when the peasant strives, he must pay dues to his superiors.

localised_text.last_approved_text: On the far-flung edges of the empire, along the fraught borders, the protection of farmland is ever a priority, especially in the Western Regions. As such, agricultural garrisons have been established. \n\n Formed of conscript soldiers, these garrisons are drafted to protect the farmland and grain supplies that form the backbone of imperial expeditions. As the Han's ambition for expansion grows, so too do these garrisons, and subsequently the need for safe supplies has never been greater.

localised_text.last_approved_text: For a peasant, life is hard. Yet even in trying times, the woes of the peasant do not seem to create woes for their masters. Mostly, in fact, magnates grow ever-wealthier from the low cost of peasant labour and the tithes exacted upon them. \n\n Those peasants who do not sacrifice their harvests instead pay a fixed, unyielding tax. Essentially, no matter how bad things become for the peasantry, the landowner is sure to turn a profit from them, no matter the cost.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If respect is shown to the earth, it will in turn respect us. Of all of master Shengzhi's advice on farming, his system of 'intensive cultivation' gained the most traction. \n\n Through the digging of either 'furrows' or 'pits', the peasant can create yields of up to 15,000 plants in a single 41 by 11 metre division. Without the need for hugely fertile fields or, crucially, oxen, this method of farming is extremely practical for even the most impoverished peasant.

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The ambitious overlord schemes against Yuan Shu, and may have designs upon my lands too!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The ambitious overlord schemes against Yuan Shu, and may have designs upon my lands too!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The capital... in ruins? You will pay for this, Dong Zhuo!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The capital... in ruins? You will pay for this, Dong Zhuo!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Surrounded by enemies, my allies - and my people! - need my protection. Heaven help any who stand in my way!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Surrounded by enemies, my allies - and my people! - need my protection. Heaven help any who stand in my way!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Is it not enough that we must suffer the ravages of ambitious warlords without also being harassed by rebels?"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Is it not enough that we must suffer the ravages of ambitious warlords without also being harassed by rebels?"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Is it not enough that we must suffer the ravages of ambitious warlords without also being harassed by rebels?"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The coalition has failed the emperor It will take great courage and decisive action to destroy the likes of Dong Zhuo!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The coalition has failed the emperor It will take great courage and decisive action to destroy the likes of Dong Zhuo!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "He might be called on for support, as long as he is not brought low by ambition and disdain for his brother."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The young emperor, Dong Zhuo's hostage. The empire rests in the tyrant's wicked grip!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The young emperor, Dong Zhuo's hostage. The empire rests in the tyrant's wicked grip!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "My former coalition allies have lost sight of our noble goals. I must rally them once more!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "My former coalition allies have lost sight of our noble goals. I must rally them once more!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel tyrant... He has been depraved by his ambitions, and must be stopped."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel tyrant... He has been depraved by his ambitions, and must be stopped."

localised_text.last_approved_text: Yuan Shao

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Yuan Shao

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The capital... in ruins? What have you wrought, Dong Zhuo!?"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The capital... in ruins? What have you wrought, Dong Zhuo!?"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers all. Their rebellion has persisted far too long."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "It is my noble duty to unite the coalition once again; by my command, Dong Zhuo will be brought to justice!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "It is my noble duty to unite the coalition once again; by my command, Dong Zhuo will be brought to justice!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "My brother, the braggart. Left unchecked, his self-interest will be our undoing!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "My brother, the braggart. Left unchecked, his self-interest will be our undoing!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The young emperor, in Dong Zhuo's hands? That tyrant means to control the empire!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The young emperor, in Dong Zhuo's hands? That tyrant means to control the empire!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel tyrant... He must be stopped, no matter the cost!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel tyrant... He must be stopped, no matter the cost!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: Yuan Shu

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Yuan Shu

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The capital lies ruined. Dong Zhuo has gone too far this time..."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The capital lies ruined. Dong Zhuo has gone too far this time..."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The Tiger of Jiangdong is a force to be reckoned with! Perhaps I might set him upon my enemies?"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The Tiger of Jiangdong is a force to be reckoned with! Perhaps I might set him upon my enemies?"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Bandits and murderers, all. I will see them driven from the land!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "My brother, the oaf... His coalition is a joke; it rests upon me to unify the land."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "My brother, the oaf... His coalition is a joke; it rests upon me to unify the land."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The fate of the people lies in the hands of lesser men. Only I have the strength - indeed, the right! - to rule!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The fate of the people lies in the hands of lesser men. Only I have the strength - indeed, the right! - to rule!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The bandit queen? Her ways are crude, but so-blunt an instrument might be well-directed at my enemies."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The bandit queen? Her ways are crude, but so-blunt an instrument might be well-directed at my enemies."

localised_text.last_approved_text: Zhang Lu

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Zhang Lu

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The young emperor? A prisoner? Troubling, but I have greater concerns."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The young emperor? A prisoner? Troubling, but I have greater concerns."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Yuan Shao's pathetic coalition is undone. He lacks the will to lead, and will fall foul of greater men,"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Yuan Shao's pathetic coalition is undone. He lacks the will to lead, and will fall foul of greater men,"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel tyrant... His machinations have wrought chaos across the land!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel tyrant... His machinations have wrought chaos across the land!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: Zhang Yan

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Zhang Yan

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The capital lies in ruins. What games is it that these nobles think they are playing?"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The capital lies in ruins. What games is it that these nobles think they are playing?"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "An unruly pack of zealots, without a doubt Such zeal might be well-directed against my enemies!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "From atop Black Mountain, man's intentions are laid bare: I will exploit their weaknesses and seize power for myself!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "From atop Black Mountain, man's intentions are laid bare: I will exploit their weaknesses and seize power for myself!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "She cares nothing for the nobles' wargames; her pursuit of power is honest, if dangerous!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "She cares nothing for the nobles' wargames; her pursuit of power is honest, if dangerous!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "So the young emperor has been captured? The Han is crumbling, and I shall reap the benefits."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "So the young emperor has been captured? The Han is crumbling, and I shall reap the benefits."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Yuan Shao's coalition descends into chaos! Let them tear themselves apart, then I will pick their bones clean."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Yuan Shao's coalition descends into chaos! Let them tear themselves apart, then I will pick their bones clean."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel tyrant... It would amuse me to bring him to heel, to discredit the feeble efforts of lesser men!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel tyrant... It would amuse me to bring him to heel, to discredit the feeble efforts of lesser men!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: Zheng Jiang

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Zheng Jiang

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The once-capital of the empire. It would seem that the nobility has been hard at work destroying itself!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The once-capital of the empire. It would seem that the nobility has been hard at work destroying itself!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "They promise salvation to the downtrodden, but it is I who will rally the people to glory!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The bandit queen, fight alongside the king of Black Mountain? Already I hear the nobles' sweet cries for mercy!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The bandit queen, fight alongside the king of Black Mountain? Already I hear the nobles' sweet cries for mercy!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "These so-called nobles want to watch the world burn? I will show them how it is done!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "These so-called nobles want to watch the world burn? I will show them how it is done!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "We find ourselves between mountains and enemies, all of which will be conquered by us!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "We find ourselves between mountains and enemies, all of which will be conquered by us!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Han Sui sits in an enviable position where few enemies can get to him. Defeating him would be a hard but worthwhile endeavour."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Han Sui sits in an enviable position where few enemies can get to him. Defeating him would be a hard but worthwhile endeavour."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "In He Yi we have a true tactician for the war ahead."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "In He Yi we have a true tactician for the war ahead."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Huang Shao is a student of the heavenly teacher and stands ready to use what he has learnt against our enemies!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Huang Shao is a student of the heavenly teacher and stands ready to use what he has learnt against our enemies!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Ma Teng has chosen to lie with the dog Dong Zhuo - I'll put them both out of their misery!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Ma Teng has chosen to lie with the dog Dong Zhuo - I'll put them both out of their misery!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I can see in Zhang Lu good intentions towards the people, but I suspect in him a deeper motive for power."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I can see in Zhang Lu good intentions towards the people, but I suspect in him a deeper motive for power."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "This one thinks much of himself and little of those around him. I must watch him very carefully."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "This one thinks much of himself and little of those around him. I must watch him very carefully."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Gong Du has a burning passion within him to bring an end to the suffering of the people!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Gong Du has a burning passion within him to bring an end to the suffering of the people!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "For me the message of our heavenly leader is clear: rid the world of illegitimate rule and bring about the Yellow Sky!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "For me the message of our heavenly leader is clear: rid the world of illegitimate rule and bring about the Yellow Sky!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Huang Shao is a student of the heavenly teacher and stands ready to use what he has learned against our enemies!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Huang Shao is a student of the heavenly teacher and stands ready to use what he has learned against our enemies!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Liu Bei's heart is with the people and theirs with him. He is noble and just; qualities I admire very much."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Liu Bei's heart is with the people and theirs with him. He is noble and just; qualities I admire very much."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Sun Jian must think highly of himself if he thinks he can take the Jade Seal without consequence!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Sun Jian must think highly of himself if he thinks he can take the Jade Seal without consequence!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The cruel fool His brazen actions only serve to help the rebellion!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Gong Du has a burning passion within him to bring an end to the people's suffering!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Gong Du has a burning passion within him to bring an end to the people's suffering!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "In He Yi we have a true tactician for the war ahead."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "In He Yi we have a true tactician for the war ahead."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I have studied with the great teacher Zhang Jue, learned the secret ways and am now ready to free the people from tyranny!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I have studied with the great teacher Zhang Jue, learned the secret ways and am now ready to free the people from tyranny!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Always he goes on about his lineage to Confucius and his elaborate works. Let's see whom, in the end, has the last say!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Always he goes on about his lineage to Confucius and his elaborate works. Let's see whom, in the end, has the last say!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Now this is a man who truly has the people in his heart. It's a shame he was born into the wrong family"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Now this is a man who truly has the people in his heart. It's a shame he was born into the wrong family"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Liu Dai is a rash fellow and rarely listens to his advisors. We can use this against him when the time is right."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Liu Dai is a rash fellow and rarely listens to his advisors. We can use this against him when the time is right."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Ha! His coalition has fallen apart and the great Yuan Shao is now friendless and vulnerable."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Ha! His coalition has fallen apart and the great Yuan Shao is now friendless and vulnerable."

localised_text.last_approved_text: Once a faction leader has earned enough prestige to be named king, they will also claim the right to rule and proclaim themselves emperor, which will make their capitals seats of great power. localised_text.last_approved_text: Once a governor faction leader has earned enough prestige to be named king, the three strongest warlords will proclaim themselves emperor, which will make their capitals seats of great power. localised_text.last_approved_text:
Once a faction leader has earned enough prestige to be named king, they will also claim the right to rule and proclaim themselves emperor, which will make their capitals seats of great power. Faction leaders can also become emperor by capturing these seats as a demonstration of their influence.

[[b]]Victory Condition[[/b]]
Unite China by bringing all emperor seats under your control.

[[b]]Victory Types[[/b]]
Standard: become emperor and eliminate all other emperors by taking their seats of power.

Co-operative: combine your strength by signing a shared mandate diplomatic deal.

Head-to-Head: destroy the other player, or compete with one another to be the first to meet the victory conditions.

localised_text.last_approved_text: He is clever and dangerous. I should ensure he knows his place!

localised_text.last_approved_text: The former emperor is less beholden to the empress than others. Perhaps he can be persuaded to defend my innocence?

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Sima Liang

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Sima Lun

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Here you can find crucial information about a character's career information.

[[img:help_mode_character_satisfaction]][[/img]] [[b]]Satisfaction[[/b]] represents a character loyalty and happiness towards their faction. Many factors play a role, such as character relationships, job satisfaction, jealousy, or dynastic matters. Satisfaction can be improved by gifting ancillaries or offering higher positions within court.

Characters who are [[b]]not deployed[[/b]] and sit idle in court become increasingly unhappy over time. [[b]]Deploy[[/b]] them as generals, send them on [[b]]assignment[[/b]] in your {{tr:map_provinces}}, or give them positions within your government.

[[img:help_mode_character_wealth]][[/img]] Another way to increase satisfaction is [[b]]promotion[[/b]]. Each character has a [[b]]title rank[[/b]] which determines their salary and also increases their satisfaction.

[[img:help_mode_character_resilience]][[/img]] Characters can earn extra [[b]]resilience[[/b]] (Romance mode only), which will enable them to survive and recover from battle wounds.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The goal of your campaign is to [[b]]unite China[[/b]] under the rule of an emperor worthy of the mandate.

This can be achieved by [[b]]proclaiming[[/b]] yourself emperor or empress once you have accumulated sufficient [[b]]prestige[[/b]]. Other warlords and leaders may strike first, however, and proclaim themselves ruler before you. In this case, you must capture their [[b]]capitals[[/b]] their seats of power to achieve victory.

To win the game, you must [[b]]control[[/b]] all emperor seats and [[b]]95 {{tr:map_regions}}[[/b]].

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_credibility]] [[b]]Credibility[[/b]]
Credibility is used for [[b]]manipulating[[/b]] diplomatic attitude in diplomacy. Use this to turn factions [[b]]against each other[[/b]], or for making sure that a certain faction [[b]]likes[[/b]] you. It can also be spent on triggering a [[b]]proxy war[[/b]], which is a war without your direct involvement.

Credibility increases [[b]]over time[[/b]] naturally. Higher faction rank will [[b]]accelerate[[/b]] this recovery.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_intimidation]] [[b]]Intimidation[[/b]]
High levels of intimidation provide strong [[b]]bonuses[[/b]] to your faction and will keep your population in line by increasing [[b]]public order[[/b]] and reducing [[b]]corruption[[/b]].

Intimidation can be increased through [[b]]executions[[/b]] (higher-ranked characters provide more intimidation), by [[b]]razing[[/b]] settlements, or by [[b]]winning battles[[/b]]. It can also be generated by [[b]]annexing[[/b]] Han Empire settlements.

Intimidation is lost by [[b]]losing battles[[/b]], and it can be spent on [[b]]promoting[[/b]] characters or to [[b]]coerce[[/b]] other factions in diplomacy. This is a powerful tool to manufacture favourable deals.

Intimidation [[b]]decays[[/b]] over time.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_unity]] [[b]]Unity[[/b]]
The cohesion within your faction is measured by unity. Unity is primarily earned by [[b]]satisfied characters[[/b]], so make sure your people are happy. [[b]]Dissatisfied[[/b]] characters will reduce unity gain. Watch out for [[b]]compatible relationships[[/b]] between characters and try to gather [[b]]loyal[[/b]] followers around you.

By spending unity, you can send characters on special [[b]]assignments[[/b]] that increase their satisfaction.

Unity can be spent on the [[b]]annexation[[/b]] of Han Empire territories; high unity will increase [[b]]prestige[[/b]] and provide other powerful [[b]]bonuses[[/b]] to your faction.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_heroism]] [[b]]Heroism[[/b]]
You can increase your heroism by [[b]]winning duels[[/b]] (as the faction leader). You also gain heroism if you [[b]]inflict more casualties[[/b]] than you receive when fighting the enemy.

Heroism [[b]]fades[[/b]] away over time, so make sure you keep proving your leadership in conflicts ahead.

High heroism will grant [[b]]recruitment[[/b]] and [[b]]upkeep[[/b]] bonuses, as well as provide [[b]]satisfaction[[/b]] to all characters.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_lineage]] [[b]]Lineage[[/b]]
Lineage is spent on [[b]]recruiting characters[[/b]] into your faction, and it can be used for more [[b]]efficient settlement occupation[[/b]].

Lineage [[b]]decays[[/b]] over time, but a [[b]]deployed[[/b]] faction leader who leads his military retinue [[b]]on the campaign map[[/b]] will provide a steady income of lineage.

The most important source for lineage are [[b]]alliances[[/b]] and [[b]]coalitions[[/b]]. You get more lineage for every [[b]]member[[/b]] in these pacts, but only if these pacts were [[b]]initiated[[/b]] by yourself.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_legitimacy]] [[b]]Legitimacy[[/b]]
High levels of legitimacy is your main source of [[b]]prestige[[/b]], and increasing your legitimacy will be an important factor for [[b]]progressing[[/b]] through the campaign.

Legitimacy can be increased through a unique [[b]]support legitimacy[[/b]] diplomatic deal, or through [[b]]vassals[[/b]] who will automatically provide legitimacy to you. It also increases over time by a small amount.

Legitimacy is spent on [[b]]recruiting characters[[/b]] into your faction, on powerful [[b]]assignments[[/b]] and [[b]]buildings[[/b]].

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Your faction resource: [[img:pooled_resource_infamy]] [[b]]Infamy[[/b]]
Infamy measures your renown within the world. It can be increased by [[b]]winning battles[[/b]] and by certain [[b]]settlement occupation options[[/b]].

Infamy [[b]]decays[[/b]] over time, so stay [[b]]offensive[[/b]] and try to not slow down.

High infamy increases [[b]]prestige[[/b]] and has other valuable [[b]]faction-wide[[/b]] effects, such as increasing your [[b]]income from tributaries[[/b]].

localised_text.last_approved_text:
[[b]]Reforms[[/b]] provide bonuses that are permanent throughout the life of a campaign.

You will immediately receive the benefits and bonuses of your chosen reform, but note that each one has a [[b]]cooldown time[[/b]] that determines how much time must pass before you can select the next.

There are five major branches in the reforms tree:

[[img:help_mode_tech_earth_administration]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_earth_law]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_earth_religion]] [[b]]government reforms[[/b]] focus on civil management of your lands and people, increasing [[b]]public order[[/b]] and [[b]]taxation[[/b]]. They also unlock further [[b]]administrator[[/b]] and [[b]]assignment[[/b]] slots.

[[img:help_mode_tech_fire_conscription]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_fire_equipment]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_fire_organisation]][[/img]] [[b]]military doctrines[[/b]] improve conscription and army organisation, making your forces more powerful and capable, and improving their [[b]]re-deployment[[/b]] capabilities.

[[img:help_mode_tech_metal_commerce]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_metal_industry]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_metal_labour]][[/img]] [[b]]infrastructure and economic reforms[[/b]] improve the local economy of your commanderies.

[[img:help_mode_tech_water_espionage]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_merchants]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_philosophy]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_trade_and_diplomacy]][[/img]] [[b]]Philosophy and trade reforms[[/b]] support your clandestine activities and improve your [[b]]trade influence[[/b]] when dealing with other factions. Philosophical reforms give you more and stronger [[b]]characters[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_tech_wood_agricultural_garrisons]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_wood_farming_and_tools]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_wood_farming_edicts]][[/img]] [[b]]Agricultural reforms[[/b]] will increase efficiency of [[b]]farming[[/b]] and other agricultural enterprises, and will increase [[b]]population growth[[/b]].

Reforms will usually always be selected in spring.

[[img:help_mode_tech_fire_conscription]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_fire_equipment]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_fire_organisation]][[/img]] [[b]]military doctrines[[/b]] improve conscription and army organisation, making your forces more powerful and capable, and improving their [[b]]re-deployment[[/b]] capabilities.

[[img:help_mode_tech_metal_commerce]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_metal_industry]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_metal_labour]][[/img]] [[b]]infrastructure and economic reforms[[/b]] improve the local economy of your commanderies.

[[img:help_mode_tech_water_espionage]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_merchants]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_philosophy]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_water_trade_and_diplomacy]][[/img]] [[b]]Philosophy and trade reforms[[/b]] support your clandestine activities and improve your [[b]]trade influence[[/b]] when dealing with other factions. Philosophical reforms give you more and stronger [[b]]characters[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_tech_wood_agricultural_garrisons]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_wood_farming_and_tools]][[/img]], [[img:help_mode_tech_wood_farming_edicts]][[/img]] [[b]]Agricultural reforms[[/b]] will increase efficiency of [[b]]farming[[/b]] and other agricultural enterprises, and will increase [[b]]population growth[[/b]].

Reforms will usually always be selected in spring.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
[[b]]Reforms[[/b]] provide bonuses that persist throughout the life of a campaign.

 The reforms in the Eight Princes campaign take time to complete, as indicated on each technology node.

 Each reform scroll is separated into four sections from top to bottom, the later sections remaining locked until your faction rank is high enough.

 The reforms are divided into three sections - [[b]]Military[[/b]], [[b]]Espionage[[/b]], and [[b]]Civic[[/b]].

 [[img:reforms_ep_military1]][[img:reforms_ep_military2]][[img:reforms_ep_military3]]Military reforms unlock new units as well as giving bonuses to armies and newly recruited units.

 [[img:reforms_ep_spy1]]Espionage reforms unlock new positions for spies and help to defend against enemy spies.

 [[img:reforms_ep_civic1]][[img:reforms_ep_civic2]][[img:reforms_ep_civic3]]Civic reforms unlock new buildings, give bonuses to help develop and upgrade commanderies, and unlock new political roles for characters within your faction.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Reforms provide bonuses that persist throughout the life of a campaign.

 Yellow Turban reforms take time to complete, as indicated on each technology node. You can increase the speed of research by constructing certain scholarly buildings.

 Each reform scroll is separated into four sections from left to right, the later sections remaining locked until your faction rank is high enough. There are even reforms that help you to increase your enlightenment and thus unlock further reforms.

 The three scrolls of reform represent the three aspects of the Yellow Turban philosophy Heaven, Land and People.

 [[img:reforms_yt_heaven1]][[img:reforms_yt_heaven2]][[img:reforms_yt_heaven3]] The Book of Heaven offers new options for scholars and upgrades to esoteric and industry buildings.

 [[img:reforms_yt_people1]][[img:reforms_yt_people2]][[img:reforms_yt_people3]] The Book of the People offers new options for healers and upgrades to housing and commerce buildings.

 [[img:reforms_yt_land1]][[img:reforms_yt_land2]][[img:reforms_yt_land3]] The Book of the Land offers new options for veterans and upgrades to farming and organisation buildings.

 Each scroll also provides faction-wide bonuses.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Times are changing for all. The emperor, long a puppet of other warlords, has abdicated, and with him the Han dynasty has ended. Who will bring peace to our turbulent lands?

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Times are changing for all. The emperor, long a puppet of other warlords, has abdicated, and with him the Han dynasty has ended. Who will bring peace to our turbulent lands?

localised_text.last_approved_text: Emperor Hui has lived a difficult and sad life, controlled by those who would seek to use him for their own ends. But now his rule is over, and a new, stronger emperor takes the throne.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Emperor Hui has lived a difficult and sad life, controlled by those who would seek to use him for their own ends. But now his rule is over, and a new, stronger emperor takes the throne.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The emperor has been taken from us by force. We must seek their return as soon as possible!

localised_text.last_approved_text: Emperor Hui has slipped our grasp and sought refuge with another prince, bestowing them the title of regent. No doubt his advisors will be scheming to direct the new regent to destroy you!

localised_text.last_approved_text: We have captured the emperor! With their power we now control much of the Han lands.
